parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on the biodiversity of subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: There is no evidence to indicate whether creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures has any desirable or harmful effects.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence base for the effectiveness of creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the observed outcomes of transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures in Australian estuaries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies in Australian estuaries have examined the effects of transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: Transplanted oysters were found to support macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were absent on structures without oysters.
[Statement 3]: The effects of transplanting organisms on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity were mixed.
[Statement 4]: The mixed effects on species richness and diversity depended on the site and the physical characteristics of the structure's surface.
[Statement 5]: In one study, transplanting oysters increased mobile invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 6]: Transplanting oysters or coralline algae did not lead to an increase in fish species richness or abundance in two out of three studies.
[Statement 7]: One study found no increase in the combined abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates after transplanting oysters.
[Statement 8]: The survival of invertebrates transplanted onto intertidal artificial structures varied based on the species, the site, and the presence of features like grooves and ridges on the surfaces.
[Statement 9]: One study noted that transplanting oysters did not increase the time fish spent interacting with the surfaces of the artificial structures.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which habitat creation methods are most effective for increasing overall species richness and diversity on intertidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm on intertidal artificial structures is the most effective method for increasing species richness and diversity.
[Statement 2]: Creating hole habitats, rock pools, or grooves on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces.
[Statement 3]: Hole habitats, rock pools, or grooves on intertidal artificial structures supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without these features.
[Statement 4]: Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 5]: Creating short flexible habitats between 1 and 50 mm on intertidal artificial structures decreased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__In European marine environments, how do the outcomes of creating textured surfaces on intertidal structures vary?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In European marine environments, creating textured surfaces on intertidal structures has shown varied outcomes.
[Statement 2]: In the UK, creating textured surfaces along with using environmentally-sensitive material had mixed effects on the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness, depending on the texture and site.
[Statement 3]: In the Netherlands, textured surfaces did not increase macroalgal abundance.
[Statement 4]: The effect of textured surfaces on invertebrate abundance is varied.
[Statement 5]: In some cases in the UK and the Netherlands, textured surfaces did not increase invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 6]: In at least one case, textured surfaces had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances.
[Statement 7]: In another case, textured surfaces increased barnacle abundance.
[Statement 8]: Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures in the UK did not increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 9]: Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures in the UK had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances depending on the site.
[Statement 10]: Topography created to mimic natural rocky reefs on intertidal artificial structures in the UK was colonized by macroalgae and limpets.
[Statement 11]: Creating textures in conjunction with using environmentally-sensitive materials has also shown mixed results.
[Statement 12]: Using ECOncrete™ with grooves, ledges, and holes increased species richness and diversity.
[Statement 13]: Limestone-cement with pits, grooves, ridges, and texture had mixed effects on richness and diversity depending on the site.
[Statement 14]: A combination of limestone-cement with pits, grooves, ridges, and texture had mixed effects on mobile invertebrate and barnacle abundance based on the site, wave-exposure, and material type.

[Statement 1]: A study in Italy found that subtidal artificial structures with harvesting restrictions had a different fish community composition compared to structures without restrictions.
[Statement 2]: Subtidal artificial structures with harvesting restrictions had higher fish species richness compared to structures without restrictions, according to a study in Italy.
[Statement 3]: One study found that a subtidal artificial structure with harvesting restrictions supported species that were absent from unrestricted structures.
[Statement 4]: A study in Italy reported similar total fish abundance around subtidal artificial structures with and without harvesting restrictions.
[Statement 5]: In one study, fish abundances around artificial structures varied by species and survey date.
[Statement 6]: One study found higher seabream abundances around a subtidal artificial structure that had harvesting restrictions.
[Statement 7]: A study in Italy reported that legally restricting human access to subtidal artificial structures did not prevent people from harvesting invertebrates and fish.
[Statement 8]: A study in Japan reported that creating small protrusions on a subtidal artificial structure had mixed effects on macroalgal abundance depending on the species.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions can enhance fish communities on subtidal artificial structures?
_gemini-2-5-pro__How do the effects of creating hole habitats versus pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures compare for biodiversity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures alters macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 2]: Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures increases species diversity or richness.
[Statement 3]: Hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures were used by sea slugs, urchins, and octopuses.
[Statement 4]: Creating hole habitats did not increase macroalgal abundance.
[Statement 5]: Creating hole habitats did not increase invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 6]: Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures alters the community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 7]: Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures increases the species richness or diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 8]: Creating pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures increases fish species richness and abundance.
[Statement 9]: The effects of creating pit habitats on invertebrate abundance were mixed.
[Statement 10]: Pit habitats did not cause an increase in macroalgal abundance.
[Statement 11]: Pit habitats were used by periwinkles, macroalgae, and invertebrates.

[Statement 1]: A controlled study in the English Channel, UK, found that artificial reef modules made of scrap tyres developed a similar sessile invertebrate community composition as traditional artificial concrete modules.
[Statement 2]: In the Mediterranean Sea, Israel, pyramid reefs made of “sea-friendly” concrete developed different invertebrate community compositions compared to reefs of either traditional concrete plinth-pole structures or bundles of traditional concrete tubes.
[Statement 3]: One controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that invertebrate species richness was lower on “sea-friendly” pyramid reefs compared to bundle reefs of traditional concrete.
[Statement 4]: Another controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that “sea-friendly” concrete pyramids had lower abundance compared to plinth-pole structures after two years.
[Statement 5]: A controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that “sea-friendly” concrete pyramids had higher abundance compared to plinth-pole structures after three years.
[Statement 6]: One replicated, controlled study in the Firth of Lorn, UK, found that the complexity of artificial reef modules had mixed effects on the abundance of edible crab and velvet swimming crab.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using environmentally-sensitive materials on subtidal artificial structures in Australia.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__In locations like Israel, the UK and Australia, how do outcomes vary when using environmentally-sensitive materials on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two studies examined the effects of managing or restricting the harvesting of species on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: A study in Gibraltar and Spain reported that restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the limpet abundance on structure surfaces.
[Statement 3]: A study in Gibraltar and Spain reported that restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures resulted in larger limpets with more balanced sex ratios than on unrestricted structures.
[Statement 4]: A study in Italy reported that legally restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures did not prevent people from harvesting invertebrates and fishes on and around the structures.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures from ceasing or altering maintenance activities on those structures.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures from controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on those structures.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the state of evidence for managing human activities, like maintenance and harvesting, on intertidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The survival of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures has been found to vary depending on the wave-exposure.
[Statement 2]: The survival of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures has been found to vary depending on the surrounding habitat.
[Statement 3]: The survival of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures has been found to vary depending on the presence and/or mesh size of cages around the transplants.
[Statement 4]: In one study, the surface orientation had no effect on the survival of transplanted canopy algae.
[Statement 5]: The growth of transplanted canopy algae was found to be dependent on wave-exposure.
[Statement 6]: The growth of transplanted canopy algae was found to be dependent on surface orientation.
[Statement 7]: The growth of transplanted canopy algae was found to be dependent on the presence of cages.
[Statement 8]: The mesh size of the cages had no effect on the growth of transplanted canopy algae in one study.
[Statement 9]: For macroalgae transplanted onto intertidal structures, survival was higher at mid- and high-shores compared to the low-shore.
[Statement 10]: The growth of macroalgae transplanted onto intertidal structures was similar across all shore heights.
[Statement 11]: The abundance of kelp recruits on a subtidal artificial structure was found to vary with the distance from the transplanted kelp individuals.
[Statement 12]: The abundance of kelp recruits on a subtidal artificial structure was found to vary with the surface orientation.
[Statement 13]: The cover of transplanted canopy algae was higher when placed under cages.
[Statement 14]: The cover of transplanted canopy algae decreased or was lower when left uncaged.
[Statement 15]: One study reported that transplanted kelp appeared to reproduce.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What factors influence the survival and growth of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating long flexible habitats (greater than 50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces.
[Statement 2]: Long flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrates, and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without the habitats.
[Statement 3]: Creating short flexible habitats (1-50mm) on intertidal artificial structures was found to alter the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community.
[Statement 4]: Creating short flexible habitats (1-50mm) on intertidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the combined mobile invertebrate and fish community.
[Statement 5]: Using environmentally-sensitive materials has been found to alter the ecological community on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 6]: Using hemp-concrete in place of standard-concrete altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 7]: Using ECOncreteTM in place of standard-concrete altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 8]: Using shell-concrete did not alter the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 9]: Using reduced-pH-concrete did not alter the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__To alter the existing ecological community on an intertidal artificial structure, which habitat modifications have been most consistently effective?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for creating adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats on artificial structures, and how does it differ between subtidal and intertidal zones?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: For creating large adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats (greater than 100 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, no studies were found that evaluated the effects on biodiversity.
[Statement 2]: Two studies were found for small adjoining cavities (less than or equal to 100 mm) on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 3]: A study in South Africa reported no alteration in mobile invertebrate community composition, species richness, or diversity on intertidal artificial structures with small adjoining cavities.
[Statement 4]: The study in South Africa did report an increase in mobile invertebrate abundance on the surfaces of intertidal artificial structures with small adjoining cavities.
[Statement 5]: A study in the UK and the Netherlands found that varying the size and arrangement of small swimthrough habitats did not increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 6]: The study in the UK and the Netherlands found that varying the size and arrangement of small swimthrough habitats did alter invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 7]: Two studies were found regarding large adjoining cavities (greater than 100 mm) on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 8]: A study in the USA revealed that large adjoining cavities on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without these habitats.
[Statement 9]: The study in the USA also revealed that large adjoining cavities on subtidal artificial structures led to an increase in overall fish species richness and abundance.
[Statement 10]: A study in Mayotte reported that large adjoining cavities on subtidal artificial structures were used by juvenile spiny lobsters, groupers, sea firs, and adult fishes.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__To improve biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures, how do the outcomes of creating natural rocky reef topography compare to creating 'rock pools'?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A UK study found that creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 2]: Another UK study observed mixed effects on the abundance of barnacles and mobile invertebrates from creating natural rocky reef topography.
[Statement 3]: The created natural rocky reef topography was colonized by macroalgae and limpets.
[Statement 4]: The creation of 'rock pools' on intertidal artificial structures has been examined in eighteen studies across various locations.
[Statement 5]: Nine out of twelve studies found that rock pools supported higher combined species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae, invertebrates, and/or fish compared to surfaces without pools.
[Statement 6]: Thirteen studies reported that rock pools supported species that were not present on structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 7]: The effects of creating 'rock pools' on species richness could be mixed.
[Statement 8]: Three studies found similar species richness in created pools and on structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 9]: The community composition and species richness in created pools could be similar or different to natural rock pools.
[Statement 10]: Two studies noted that a variety of marine life used created rock pools.

[Statement 1]: Transplanting or seeding organisms onto subtidal artificial structures can affect algal abundance.
[Statement 2]: The cover of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures in Italy and Croatia increased when placed under cages.
[Statement 3]: The cover of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures in Italy and Croatia decreased when left uncaged.
[Statement 4]: The abundance of kelp recruits on a subtidal artificial structure in Japan varied depending on the distance from transplanted kelp individuals.
[Statement 5]: The abundance of kelp recruits on a subtidal artificial structure in Japan varied depending on the surface orientation.
[Statement 6]: Kelp transplanted onto a subtidal artificial structure appeared to reproduce.
[Statement 7]: Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on intertidal artificial structures was not found to increase macroalgal abundance in two studies conducted in the Netherlands.
[Statement 8]: Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures had mixed effects on macroalgal abundance.
[Statement 9]: The effects of creating short flexible habitats on macroalgal abundance varied by species group.
[Statement 10]: The effects of creating short flexible habitats on macroalgal abundance varied by site.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What interventions can be used to increase algal abundance on marine artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden, creating large hole habitats on artificial structures altered the community composition.
[Statement 2]: Large hole habitats on artificial structures in subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden supported species that were not present on surfaces without such habitats.
[Statement 3]: In studies of subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden, some found that creating large hole habitats on artificial structures increased species richness and/or diversity.
[Statement 4]: In studies of subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden, one study found that creating large hole habitats on artificial structures did not increase species richness or diversity.
[Statement 5]: The effects of large hole habitats on the abundance of invertebrates and fish in subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden were varied, with some studies showing no increase or mixed results.
[Statement 6]: In intertidal zones in Australia, the UK, and Israel, adding large hole habitats increased the species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 7]: In intertidal zones in Australia, the UK, and Israel, large hole habitats supported species that were otherwise absent from the artificial surfaces.
[Statement 8]: Studies in the Netherlands and Australia indicated that large holes on artificial structures did not increase or had mixed effects on the abundance of invertebrates and macroalgae.
[Statement 9]: A study in Australia documented the use of large hole habitats by sea slugs, urchins, and octopuses.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do the biodiversity outcomes of creating large hole habitats (>50mm) on artificial structures vary between subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden versus intertidal zones in Australia and Europe?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges on intertidal and subtidal artificial structures has been shown to have various ecological effects.
[Statement 2]: On intertidal structures, these features have altered the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 3]: On intertidal structures, these features have supported species that were not present on surfaces without them.
[Statement 4]: Some studies found that adding grooves and protrusions to artificial structures led to an increase in the overall species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 5]: Other studies reported that adding grooves and protrusions to artificial structures had mixed effects on species diversity and richness, depending on factors like the site, shore level, and the specific design of the features.
[Statement 6]: For subtidal structures, creating grooves and protrusions altered the community composition.
[Statement 7]: For subtidal structures, creating grooves and protrusions supported species that were previously absent.
[Statement 8]: For subtidal structures, creating grooves and protrusions increased species richness and diversity.
[Statement 9]: Other studies on subtidal structures found mixed effects on community composition and species richness depending on the orientation of the structure's surfaces.
[Statement 10]: Studies have reported mixed results for species abundance on intertidal structures where grooves and protrusions have been added.
[Statement 11]: Some studies found an increase in overall species abundance when features on intertidal structures were paired with water-retaining covers.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found no change in overall species abundance on intertidal structures after the addition of grooves and protrusions.
[Statement 13]: Some studies found mixed effects on overall species abundance on intertidal structures after the addition of grooves and protrusions.
[Statement 14]: The abundance of invertebrates such as limpets and mussels increased in some cases where grooves and protrusions were added to artificial structures.
[Statement 15]: In some cases, barnacle abundance did not increase when grooves and protrusions were added to artificial structures.
[Statement 16]: Fish abundance and richness on intertidal structures generally did not increase with the addition of grooves and protrusions.
[Statement 17]: An increase in juvenile salmon feeding activity was observed on intertidal structures after the addition of grooves and protrusions.
[Statement 18]: On subtidal structures, the addition of grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 19]: Habitats created by grooves and small protrusions were reported to be colonized by various organisms, including microalgal species, macroalgae, and non-mobile invertebrates.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the general ecological effects of simultaneously creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges on artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures in Australia had mixed effects on the abundance of non-mobile and mobile invertebrates.
[Statement 2]: The effect of creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures on invertebrate abundance depended on the species group and the site.
[Statement 3]: A study in the UK found that creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances.
[Statement 4]: The effects of creating natural rocky reef topography on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances depended on the site.
[Statement 5]: The use of different materials for intertidal artificial structures has been studied for its effects on invertebrate populations.
[Statement 6]: In the UK, using hemp-concrete or shell-concrete in place of standard-concrete was found to increase the combined abundance of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates.
[Statement 7]: Hemp-concrete also increased mobile invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 8]: Shell-concrete did not increase mobile invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 9]: In studies in Australia, the UK, and Ireland, using sandstone instead of basalt did not lead to an increase in the abundance of tubeworms, oysters, limpets, barnacles, or combined invertebrates.
[Statement 10]: Reducing the pH of concrete did not lead to an increase in the abundance of tubeworms, oysters, limpets, barnacles, or combined invertebrates in studies in Australia, the UK, and Ireland.
[Statement 11]: The use of limestone-cement with added textures such as pits, grooves, or ridges had mixed effects on mobile invertebrate and barnacle abundance.
[Statement 12]: Altering the composition of concrete had mixed effects on mobile invertebrate and barnacle abundance.
[Statement 13]: The effects of altering concrete composition or using limestone-cement with added textures depended on the site, wave-exposure, and the specific type of material tested.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of ceasing or altering maintenance activities on intertidal artificial structures.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the state of evidence for controlling or removing non-native species on artificial marine structures to benefit biodiversity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Out of twenty-two studies examining the effects of creating pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures, four of six replicated, controlled studies found that creating these pits altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 2]: Three replicated, controlled studies reported that pit habitats supported macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitats.
[Statement 3]: Eight of twelve replicated controlled studies found that creating pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity on structure surfaces.
[Statement 4]: Two of five replicated, controlled studies found that creating pit habitats increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces.
[Statement 5]: One study found that creating pits decreased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 6]: One study found that creating pits had no effect on the combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 7]: Five studies examined the effects of creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 8]: One replicated, randomized, paired sites, controlled, before-and-after study found that creating hole habitats on an intertidal artificial structure altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 9]: Three replicated, controlled studies reported that hole habitats supported macroalgae and/or non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 10]: Three replicated, controlled studies found that creating hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces.
[Statement 11]: One of two replicated, controlled studies reported that creating hole habitats on an intertidal artificial structure did not increase the invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces.
[Statement 12]: One study found that creating holes had mixed effects on limpet abundance, depending on the shore level and site.
[Statement 13]: One study reported that hole habitats created on an intertidal artificial structure, along with rock pools, were used by sea slugs, urchins and octopuses.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do the biodiversity outcomes of creating small pits (1-50 mm) versus larger holes (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures compare?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What interventions have been shown to alter the overall community composition of organisms on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating groove habitats, small ledges, holes, and using environmentally-sensitive material on a subtidal artificial structure altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces.
[Statement 2]: Creating short flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures altered the non-mobile invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 3]: Reducing the frequency of cleaning on subtidal artificial structures did not alter the combined invertebrate and fish community composition on and around the structure's surfaces.
[Statement 4]: Creating grooves and small protrusions on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the community composition.
[Statement 5]: Creating short flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the community composition.

[Statement 1]: In the UK, creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not lead to an increase in the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 2]: Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures in the UK had mixed effects on the abundance of barnacles and mobile invertebrates.
[Statement 3]: The artificial topography on intertidal structures in the UK was observed to be colonized by macroalgae and limpets.
[Statement 4]: Limpets utilized the shaded grooves and water-retaining features of the artificial topography on intertidal structures in the UK.
[Statement 5]: A study in Italy on subtidal artificial structures found that creating natural rocky reef topography did not result in an increase in the abundance of juvenile canopy macroalgae that settled on the surfaces.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that using hemp-concrete or shell-concrete in place of standard-concrete on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate abundance on the surfaces of the structures.
[Statement 2]: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that the use of hemp-concrete also increased the mobile invertebrate species richness on the surfaces of the structures.
[Statement 3]: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that the use of shell-concrete did not increase the mobile invertebrate species richness on the surfaces of the structures.
[Statement 4]: Two of four replicated, controlled studies in Australia, the UK, Singapore and Ireland found that using sandstone in place of basalt on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the abundance of tubeworms, oysters, limpets, barnacles and/or combined invertebrates on the surfaces of the structures.
[Statement 5]: Two of four replicated, controlled studies in Australia, the UK, Singapore and Ireland found that reducing the pH of concrete on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the abundance of tubeworms, oysters, limpets, barnacles and/or combined invertebrates on the surfaces of the structures.
[Statement 6]: Two studies found that using limestone-cement, along with creating pits, grooves, small ridges and texture, had mixed effects on the mobile invertebrate and/or barnacle abundance, depending on the site, wave-exposure and/or the type of material tested.
[Statement 7]: Two studies found that altering the composition of concrete had mixed effects on the mobile invertebrate and/or barnacle abundance, depending on the site, wave-exposure and/or the type of material tested.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of ceasing or altering maintenance on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: For subtidal artificial structures, one study found that reducing the frequency of cleaning did not alter the invertebrate and fish community, combined abundance, or richness.
[Statement 3]: Reducing the frequency of cleaning on subtidal artificial structures did increase macroalgal abundance.
[Statement 4]: Reducing the frequency of cleaning on subtidal artificial structures did not increase the survival or growth of transplanted oysters.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that assessed the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: There is no evidence to show whether the action of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on intertidal artificial structures has positive or negative effects.
[Statement 3]: No studies were discovered that assessed the impact of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species from subtidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating large ledges (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, in conjunction with grooves and small protrusions, was found in one of two studies to increase the combined macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrate species diversity.
[Statement 2]: A separate study reported that creating large ridges along with large protrusions did not lead to an increase in the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 3]: For small ridges or ledges (1–50 mm), one of two studies found no increase in combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 4]: Two studies revealed that small ridges or ledges supported lower species richness compared to the grooves created between the small ridges or ledges.
[Statement 5]: Creating large ledges with grooves and small protrusions was shown to increase the combined abundance of macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrates in one study.
[Statement 6]: Two studies found that creating large ledges or ridges with other features increased the abundance of mussels or limpets.
[Statement 7]: Creating large ledges or ridges with other features did not increase the abundance of barnacles.

parts.text:

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The effects of creating swimthrough habitats on artificial structures have been investigated in both subtidal and intertidal environments.

[Statement 4]: Other studies noted the presence of fish species on structures with small swimthroughs that were not found on structures without swimthroughs.

[Statement 6]: Small swimthroughs were observed to be used by a variety of marine life, including juvenile spiny lobsters, sea firs, and both adult and juvenile fish.
[Statement 7]: For large swimthroughs (greater than 100 mm) on subtidal structures, studies have reported an increase in overall fish species richness and abundance.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Using shell-concrete or quarried rock instead of standard-concrete on subtidal artificial structures was found in six out of eleven studies to alter the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the surfaces of the structures.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Eighteen studies into the creation of ‘rock pools’ on intertidal artificial structures have taken place in various locations.
[Statement 2]: Studies on creating rock pools have occurred in estuaries in Australia, the UK, and the eastern USA.
[Statement 3]: Studies on creating rock pools have occurred on open coastlines in the UK, Ireland, and southeast Spain.
[Statement 4]: Studies on creating rock pools have occurred in straits in the UK and Malaysia, and in a marina in Australia.
[Statement 5]: In thirteen studies across Australia, the UK, the USA, Spain, and Malaysia, created rock pools were found to support macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species.
[Statement 6]: The species supported by created rock pools were absent from the surfaces of the artificial structures.
[Statement 7]: One study in Australia showed that created rock pools had mixed effects on community composition.
[Statement 8]: The mixed effects on community composition in the Australian study depended on the depth of the pool, the shore level, and the site.
[Statement 9]: A study in Ireland revealed that shore level and wave-exposure influenced the community composition of created rock pools.
[Statement 10]: A study in Ireland found that created rock pools that were sheltered from waves filled with sediment within a two-year timeframe.
[Statement 11]: Nine out of twelve studies in Australia, the UK, Spain, and Malaysia indicated that the creation of rock pools led to a higher diversity and/or richness of species compared to structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 12]: The higher diversity and/or richness was observed for combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and/or fish species.
[Statement 13]: A study in Australia reported that adding short flexible habitats into created rock pools had mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae, invertebrates and fish.
[Statement 14]: The outcomes of adding short flexible habitats into created rock pools varied by species group and by site.
